pros:
It's a gamble- but you're not stuck with the same miserable people every trip. And you're not stuck with the same passengers every flight. You make lifelong friendships when you can find good people to fly with. Buddy bidding makes these miserable, inhumane trips more enjoyable. 

It's becoming increasingly more diverse in the flight deck which- judging by some of the comments is upsetting the old guard. It must be difficult to be a new, qualified individual and have to deal with people assuming you're only there because you're a person of color taking a white person's place. 

Long strings of days off at a time is nice. Your time off is your own- no taking work home.
cons:
If an incident occurs on the plane, the Captain- who gets paid the big bucks to make executive decisions- usually makes the decision to hide in the cockpit and shout unhelpful information to you through the phone- and that's if the pilots acknowledge you at all.

The flight benefits are laughable- you can never get on because AA notoriously oversells flights. Because they do this, every gate is full of irate people so the agents are stressed and take it out on you. There is seldom comradery between employees. I get treated better as a non-rev on other airlines and try to avoid flying on AA- even if it means paying. Agents will throw you under the bus if there is a delay- they will blame you on the PA. 

Passengers had become increasingly more hostile since 2016- which correlates with the drastic, polarizing change of political landscape in this country. The same people now think that wearing a mask is against their "constitutional rights" and now have a violent mob mentality.

When I first started, there were longer layovers and fewer flights per day. Then when the merge with US Airways happened, we started getting 3-4 flights per day with just enough time in the destination to eat, sleep, and do it all over again.

Senior flight attendants are slow to adapt, grossly incompetent yet take all the good trips. If they'd interviewed between 2012-2022, a lot of these people would not make the cut. They were hired for their looks and the job market was less competitive. Newhires are more educated, level-headed and culturally sensitive. But have to deal with Seniors talking about how they "paid their dues" when they got to experience 20+ years of the job being enjoyable, easier and worth it.

You can't make plans- flexibility is difficult because you have no control. 

It is a dead end job, unless you are willing to move to godforsaken Texas and deal with incompetent management.

The pay is HORRENDOUS. I was always broke. Like the military, they put you wherever they need you. But unlike the military if you live in expensive places like San Francisco, New York or Boston, there is no pay differential. And in SFO and BOS the flying is very limited and very senior.

The union is a joke. Because the union is made up of active FAs, they care more about how they look, their job security and protecting their buddies than representing people in a neutral manner.

review_title: Truly a diverse place, best in the industry travel benefits and great people working here
pros:
- As a POC, I haven’t worked anywhere as diverse as American. I feel welcomed here and there are a lot of Employee Business Resources Groups from all identities and they’re pretty active. Our executive leadership are also active in some of the events the EBRGs organize which is refreshing and inspiring to see.

- Leadership especially middle management is very diverse. It’s one thing for companies (especially other airlines) that claim they’re diverse but that number mostly comes from front lines employees. But to also see diversity in leadership is truly inspiring.

- I truly feel like our executive leadership cares about each employee. 

- Our travel benefits are not seniority base unlike most other airlines, so it’s beneficial for younger or more junior employees. My partner and I have been everywhere including international destinations and most times, business class. Domestic is definitely more tricky but you’re still able to make it work.

- The mentors I have met here and the people willing to connect with you over a 30 minute coffee chat have been amazing. They’re so willing to help younger employees like myself. I’ve seen some of my colleagues even network with VPs and I feel that’s rare for such a large company. 

- Most people you meet traveling are wonderful, friendly and look out for you as a teammate. This is true for gate agents, flight attendants, etc.
cons:
- Certain departments like mine are still pretty old school. It’s not as diverse as the company as a whole. 

- Huge company so it’s hard to make an impact in most of your projects 

- Our product, service standards and operations need a lot of improvement 

- Leadership needs to stop being so reactive and think of ways AA can lead the pack rather than waiting to see what other airlines are doing 

- Corporate Coms need to do a better job in communicating new product, services and enhancements. They need to highlight the stories that make American a wonderful company. I truly believe in the company and it just needs to be conveyed to the public.
